The game is so much fun, especially if you are in a group of 2 or more!  You have to ALWAYS think two steps ahead: Each season holds it unique problems you will have to face. The extrem cold in winter and lack of food, the unbearing heat and random bush fires in summer. And every day you have to manage to gather enough resources to push through. Food, wood, gold, stone, string, gears..... oh and then at the same time you have to watch your sanity!  The game seemed simple, but surviving is a difficult task! I highly recommend anyone who is has bought this game to watch some tutorials, or else the first seasons will be painful. Buy it, play it, LOVE IT!  I give this game a solid 10/10!

Don't Starve Together, a game that could forge a bond built from trust, survival and passion. However, it is more likely to be the game that causes you to die in any number of ways (many of which are not starving) while your friends either frantically attempt to save you or laugh at you to your dismay, sometimes both.            Positive's   +Diverse game play which will allow every play though to be special in its own way +A verity of enjoyable characters which you will soon become attached and feel a sense of genuine pity for them and their struggles +Challenges the world present will remain interesting and keep the player hooked. +Good price for what you get +Chester  Negative's  -The increased health of the creatures (especially the giants) can be considered unaccommodating to players in small groups or pairs -Only one Chester...  Overall this game can be considered a massively entertaining game to play with friends as well as one which will keep you playing for hours to come. Overall review 9/10.

[h1]Backstory of How I Got Into Don't Starve ([u][b]Skip to Next Header To Read Review[/b][/u])[/h1]   Don't Starve was a game that I bought on my birthday back in 2013. I had no idea what to expect from it when I bought it. When I eventually played it I found that I loved the mechanics, the gameplay and the artstyle. Everything about Don't Starve was great!  Then came along the first DLC for the game, Reign of Giants. It was a great addition to the game (even if I was scared to play it due to all of the new bosses.   After Reign of Giants came out I thought to myself, "Hey, this would be great with multiplayer". I hoped and prayed that multiplayer would be added to one of my all time favorite games for many months, but on the inside I knew that it never would come out.  When I heard that it did I lit up, I signed up for the beta and watched many youtube videos on it (By the way, I never got into the beta).  The second the game dropped on steam I bought it and sent the extra copy to my friend. We played for many months but eventually stopped playing after we lost a good world. Recently I picked up the game again and my friends and I have been having a blast!  [h1]Review of Don't Starve Together[/h1] [u][b]DISCLAIMER![/b] This Review Was Made On 08/18/2016[/u]  Don't Starve Together is a game all about, well, not starving together... or not buring to death during summer together... or not being eaten by a giant one-eyed bird... or not being mauled to death by a pack of ravenous hounds together... Look you get the point. It's a game all about using teamwork to survive in the evil world that Maxwell has created for Wilson in Don't Starve.  Teamwork can be very helpful but at the same time it can tear you apart. You will eventually run out of food, and when you do, you are bound to turn on your friends and blaim them for "taking" the food for themselves.  The gameplay of Don't Starve Together is almost exactly the same as in Don't Strave, except this time around there are new items to use that benefit your friends and yourself in the longrun.   Working as a team in the world of Don't Starve makes the game a hell of a lot easier for you, being able to have one person go out and get berries as you chop down wood greatly increases your chance of survival. The only thing wrong with working together is sharing of resources. This causes you to have to go out and get more food fast so you... Don't Starve. The only way to be sure that you don't fully run out of food is by raising the regrowth rate of plants and by raising the level of berries and carrots that will spawn.  [h1]Summary[/h1] Overall, Don't Starve is a great game for anyone who is looking for a fun yet hard survival game. It is also good for anyone who was a fan of the original Don't Starve.  One key point to note is that, you can play Don't Starve Together alone, making it almost the same as the base game.  It is also important to note that Reign of Giants is free with Don't Starve together. This doesn't mean that you will get if for Don't Starve as well, you'll still have to buy it separately. But honestly who cares, just buy Reign of Giants too. Klei is a great company that makes great games, so why not support them in any way possible.  I give Don't Starve Together a 10/10. It is a perfect game that deserves the overwhelmingly positive reviews that it is getting.  [h1][b]IMPORTANT FUTURE NOTE FOR DON'T STARVE TOGETHER![/b][/h1]  The Shipwrecked DLC that was released for Don't Starve is not currently part of Don't Starve Together but it most likely will be in the next few months (or at least by 2017 hopefully).  It is also important to note that all future DLC for Don't Starve will not be available for Don't Starve Together until months after it is released for Don't Starve. [b]So if they release a DLC for Don't Starve that adds more pets and monsters in the month of March, don't expect it to come out until around October of the same year for Don't Starve Together.[/b]

There are times I'm loving this game and there are times I'm groaning in boredom or frustration with this game. It takes a game or two to grasp the basics. Once you get the idea down though it's a fairly easy [strike]to play[/strike] to know what to do.  Find food. Find rocks. Find wood. Make tools. Build a camp site.   After that?  Explore. Advance your camp site with things you find. Find or build additional methods of gathering food. Build things to defend yuorself with when fights happen.  The problem with this game mostly comes with death. When you die you turn into a ghost and watch as your body poofs into a skeleton and drops your intire inventory on the ground for you to fetch when you return alive. The long trip back to the spawn tends to be the largest issue for me. If you went miles out to explore new area you have to walk - as a ghost - miles back to the spawn where you started the game. There you resurect in a new body, and then you walk miles back to the place you died and collect your old inventory - stopping for nights of course since travel during night kills you (again). And then miles back to get home again - with night as downtime again. Death is [b]expensive[/b] in terms of time.  If you happened to die in Winter you'll never make it back to camp since you don't come back to life with a thermal stone (an item that keeps you from freezing to death during Winter). And you can't make a thermal stone on the spot. You need ingredients for it. Which you don't start with. you have no time to get these ingredients either since you start freezing only five steps into the cold. Unless you built your camp right at the spawn or you had the foresight to set up a stone-liked campfire and some wood (and possibly a thermal stone) at the spawn you're likely perminantly dead if you die in Winter.  Death is unforgiving as well. each time you die your max HP lowers. Why they thoguht that was a good idea baffles me. If you couldn't survive with 150 HP you know you won't survive with a max HP of 30 (about 2 hits if you wear armor). This isn't unfixable. You can craft booster shots that refill the max little by little. But you have to get the ingredients for these from monsters which have a possibility of lowering your max HP further.  But I have a theory that making death so harsh makes you as a player strongly favor survival over taking a chance. And it brings players to strongly desire working as a team over being greedy by knowing you'll need the help of others to safely build booster shots and help when death becomes imminent. I won't lie though; the times I have to spend 11 minutes over a corpse run are times I start thinking it'd be more fun to play something else.  The best part of the game is when you start putting together a pretty awesome camp. The feeling of accomplishment is powerful. Having nearby allies against attacks, a reliable food source, a stockpile of tools and replacements, and pure desire to see what else is out there with your friend(s).  The art style of the game originally threw me. I probably would have tried it sooner than I did if it didn't have the clunky paper drawing look. But after actually trying the game it struck me kinda cute and quirky. the characters to choose from leave me wondering if they were programmed correctly though. One says they're comfortable in darkness but their sainity drops like any of the others does soon as night time pops.  I can't help but feel the downsides of this game will be fixed up in time. It's early access after all.

TL;DR formed a communist spider union while controlling the capitalist human populace via market influence  >join vanilla server with 7 other players (8 players max) >pick webber >2 others are also webber >1 wormwood, will be important later >filthy humans of different kinds combine forces to make a camp near a beefalo herd >me and sp00ders head off into the great white north >establish our own camp >plant sp00der nests a bit away from the camp >already a limitless supply of food due to webber not receiving penalties from eating monster meat and simple traps being able to instakill sp00ders, so starving is out of the question. >practice the art of sp00der agriculture, camp flourishes beautifully and we have an incredible supply of silk and spider glands >everyone has their own tent, meat and tools are shared equally, all is good >human camp never finds any wild sp00der nests, get desperate for silk >establish a market for silk, in exchange for whatever the sp00der union requires at the time (charcoal, living logs, you get it) >sp00ders not trust filthy humans, they might steal silk, or give away the location of our base >eventually work out an agreement that the single wormwood will be our mediator and deliverer (the two camps are VERY far away) >eventually become one of the only reliable sources of food in winter >deliver daily rations of meatballs made from monster meat (removes negative effects of said meat) to human camp in exchange for various goods >realize we can pull the agreement any time and let them starve to death, less mouths to feed >extra labor proves to be more useful than not, so we decide to keep the human population under our control  honestly the most fun public game session i've had in a while.

Don't Starve (Don't Starve Together also) is one of an elite few on my favorite games list. I caught the game somewhere on the internet when it was a beta iOS title and it was running via an emulator of some sort. I was instantly in love and kept telling people about it. But they thought I was crazy and said no one wants to play a game like that, sounds like too much work. Wrong they were! (Channeled a bit of Yoda there)   It's in my top 5 favorite games of all time. It's on an even more elite list of mine. I've purchased this game, no less than 6 times (possibly more). I bought Don't Starve for both my PC and my iPad (sometimes you're stuck somewhere you don't want to be. Nothing like pulling out your iPad at the Drs Office and playing some DS. Parents LOVE when they see me, because their kids crowd around to quietly watch...and occassional adult too). I've bought the game numerous times as gifts for other people, including my own daughter (we even did a version of Hard Knock Life (It's a Don't Starve Life) about the game. I rarely if ever buy a game more than once and for more than one console, unless I LOVE a game. I dare say I will still be playing this game when I'm a dottering old grandmother. Telling my grand kids..now THIS..this is how you make a good game. Watch and learn kids..watch and learn.  Highly recommended!

A hoot to play on beefed-up worlds and talk with people- make jokes, burn forest, etc.  If you don't feel like challenges, spawn all the stuff you need and make a gameshow  Become God  Strike people with lightning bolts  Download hilarious (and helpful) mods  Community: hyped for updates and gameplay  Trap people in walls  Kill giants  Screw with the game  Spawn in more giants to kill  Dress in the most obscene clothes  Become an idiot  Go cave-diving  Get killed by amazingly hard bosses  Realize that some people can take down those bosses on day 5  Try and spend the rest of the day learning tactics to be the very best  Become a better God  Eat waffles   Can you buy the game already?

As someone who hasn't played the single player version that much I still wholeheartedly recommend this game.   You are going to get the most out of it with at least three friends. Talking and planning is essential here – maybe you will see your buddies in a new light after a few hours of a desperate battle against the many odds the game throws against you.   Beware: human emotions tend to go haywire in dangerous situations. You'll know what I mean if you ever built – what you thought was – a reasonably stable ecosystem only to completely be bamboozled by some irresponsible action of a friend.  Life will be tough but it's addicting. Especially together!  + realistic simulation of being lost in the wildernis with your friends. (=you die) + lovely graphics + the well goes deep: there's much to explore + endless replayability + intuitive gameplay (this one's a must) + stuff gets patched and refined regularly + you can burn forests!  - main menu is a bit confusing to use with the controller - you may lose a friend or two - you can burn your camp  Nomitated this game for the “Best Use Of A Farm Animal” Award.

Hiya, today im giving a review on the game, Don't Starve Together. This game has its pros and cons of course, like any other game I will honestly rate it!  Don't Starve Together is a game currently in Beta made off the game Don't Starve, you must survival the dark and twisted world. Weird giants and creatures all around, harsh weather conditions, the horrid wave of hounds you always forget about until you see the words, "The hounds are baying!" This game is definitly a game you want to try with friends or maybe on your own, you work together or not, and attempt survival. It is difficult at first to be honest, but as the game goes on it gets alot better :)  Pros~ Character Variety(Workshop Aswell) Art style Voices are instruments Never ending Laughs and scares for all X3 A fun coop game  Cons~ Can be very difficult at times Hackers do exist Furries on Workshop Everything will kill  To sum up the game, I'd give it a 9/10, I play it with my friend Tori all the time and it's always fun, never ever do we get tired of playing it. We suck so we usually cheat. I don't like the hounds but you can turn them off, now they have gifts :D And the game gets better and better after each update :)  Buy it even if it isn't on sale, I bought the 4 pack and gave some to friends to play. You won't regret this purchase at all :)

A little weird to me that you either wait for the launch of this game to get don't starve together, or get a free copy of it at launch when you own the game. These games typically are a bit weird because you never get an unfinished copy of it until it's done. However it is a quirky little fun game that's 2D. Typical old school point and click type game for movement where you point and click on floor. Movement is a weird because of the graphics and the character gets stuck or has problems moving around things at times in order to pick things up. Could use more work. The devs actually put out updates and fix things. They have been timely with caring and tending for their game. This is your typical survival game. You can actually beat it in adventure mode but it is very short and not much gameplay is offered there.   You can build but it is very limitted. No roof's or shelters for you either. You can make things like umbrellas but you will never have true shelter other than building a fence. The fences are not durable and there are no gates available. It's a chore constantly breaking things to get in and out of your fenced area. Storage isn't good. Crafting storage takes a lot of wood and offers very little space. You end up crafting 30 or more just to keep your things stored. You can't really build too much and you can't rely on farming because in the winter nothing grows. You can survive from animals you hunt or stored rabits as well as other things here and there like birds. Provided, that you prepared and stocked up on items to survive. The game offers seasons which may or may not make things a tad more difficult due to weather changing.   Food will spoil quickly even in a craftable ice box. I suggest storing rabits with traps you made to catch them in storage chests so you can avoid the spoiling of food through the winter. Each storage chest can hold up to only 9 items. The idea is get what you can and survive while preparing for winter. Collect and gather resources and craft items to survive or play adventure mode and survive. At night if no light is made by you, you will die and just about anything else can kill you as well. Fun for a few hours but not enough to keep you busy for months. I pop in and out of it as new things become available.   Several mods for this edition of the game as well as the original version of the game. Recommended for short gaming sessions for those who want a much easier and funnier survival game. There are ways to avoid death by crafting armor or touching a touching stone or getting supplies to make magic items non stop that can aid you to stay alive. But if not prepapered you will die and have to restart your game again as there is perma death. However in this version of the game you can come back to life if you have your settings set for that.   This version is almost the same as the original version of the game but allows for playing with other people you pick or with randoms. You can very easily play with other people with little to no hassle or set up on your end. You do not need to deal with port forwarding settings which makes this co-op experience more attractive to newbies. Their wiki for the game is a bit weird to use and no search bar is even provided so I suggest just reading forums or talking with their community for help or ideas. Although it is not really needed as they game shows you what you can and can not craft. Making it so much easier rather than playing a survival game where you have to be glued to a wiki page because the game failed at teaching you anything or showing you what you could and couldn't do. I am really liking the games that clearly show you what is going on and what you can make. Enjoy! :)

What I like the most about Don’t Starve Together is how new content is regularly being added by the devs and It’s got an amazing community that’s constantly pumping amazing workshop mods like crazy.  Although the game has lots of content and an amazing art style, it can be really hard to get into for it doesn't really do a great job at teaching you how things work... and perhaps that was intended by the devs. Regardless, unless you're constantly looking at the wiki, using overpowered mods or you’re playing with someone who has a decent amount of experience with the game, you are guaranteed to die a lot. It can be really frustrating, specially if you’re playing solo. But if you are willing overcome the frustration, it might become one of your favorite games.

Definitely a one-of-a-kind survival Co-Op game. I'm generally not interested in the odd anime type games, but DST is my first exception. This game will definitely charm you, and get you addicted. Solid game-play, no issues at all with stability, controls, etc and I'm running an older machine  that I built 10 years ago (GFX were updated a few years ago, specs in my profile).  Hands down the best co-op survival experience on Steam, that doesn't require mad hardware requirements. Despite that, the game is still quite aesthetically pleasing (eye candy). Worth every penny of the asking price!  Pick it up for yourself, and fall in love with DST.  **Disclaimer: I'm not responsible for any addiction, or relationships spawning from DST if my review helped persuade you to buy the game.

Klei Entertainment's Don't Starve Together (DST) is a fun standalone expansion to the single-player game Don't Starve. DST is an unforgivable and tense co-op (optional) survival game with a Gothic/Tim Burton-esque inspired aesthetic. DST forces the player to learn through trial and error in order to not only sustain themselves but progress as well. While the game's survival, exploration, and crafting can become repetitive over time, the reward is in learning how to get further each time you play and discovering new things like items and creatures specific to their respective season and/or biome. The unfortunate downside to the lack of reward system other than experiencing the in-game world is that you will eventually see everything—and when you do, there is nothing else to get excited about.   [table] [tr] 	[th][h1]Score: [i]8/10[/i][/h1][/th] [/tr] [/table]  [u][b]Pros[/b][/u] • Distinct art style and atmosphere  • Massive randomized worlds to explore • Diverse group of characters with different abilities to choose from  [u][b]Cons[/b][/u] • Lacking in variety of biome-specific creatures • Lacks enough rewards to balance out the repetition  • Steep learning curve keeps it from being more accessible

Um dos jogos + Engraçados e desafiantes que joguei. Dificil pois todos os status descem constante mente o que faz com que voçes estejam sempre em pressão  Falta de comida? Podem caçar, cultivar , e como é online porque nao robar um pouco de carne na base inimiga? Sanidade? Há varias actividades entre um vasto leque de personagens que podes utilizar. Uns ao apanhar flores outros plantando arvores e outros simplesmente lutando. HP ? Isso Para mim ainda é um grande desafio pois quando perco vida começo logo a rezar, eu proprio sei que existem varias maneiras de recuperar hp entre comer e fazer curativos mas todos eles minimamente desafiantes de os ter.  Em relação há parte grafica do jogo em si só tenho a dizer, Ideia de genio, juntare um mundo desenhado a um jogo, simplista mas muito bem feito. As musicas ligam simplesmente de uma maneira prefeita ao graficos do jogo com uma banda sonora variada para as diferentes partes do dia e para varios eventos que possam ocurrer.  O menu tem tudo o que se pede desde configuraçoes até a um pequeno toque de charme em que aparece as pessoas com quem jogamos anteriormente.  Para mim um jogo Fantastico no qual gostei de passar algumas horitas a jogar.  Recomendo vivamente  8/10

Don't Starve Together is exactly what it says on the tin; not starving... together.   The game itself is solid, and runs well, even on my crap laptop. There is pretty much all of the original content included, minus Adventure Mode and the Shipwrecked DLC (not original content, but whatever).  There are many great mods out there for this game, from things to make the game easier or harder, adding new features or characters, or just tweaking small things here and there. In addition, making a mod for this game is surprisingly easy, and there are many great tutorials out there to help you along the way.  All in all, I think that Don't Starve Together is a great game, and only £11 for pretty much two copies of Don't Starve and the Reign of Giants DLC, where can you go wrong? Either work together to survive, or run around setting forests alight whilst your buddy is eaten by spiders, or even break the game by spawning a million chesters from two eyebones, the game is great.  8.5/10  (I neglected to mention the online community, since I only play this game with my friends).

I see a lot of "this game is boring" or complaints about the game's mechanics. there is a website for the latter and for the former, most haven't played past 10 hours. shame on you.  i try to be as "real" as possible in my reviews (unless i just don't want to); i want to give my honest opinion.  first off, i dislike survival games heavily, but DST and DS is just so fun. the reasons as to why i love this game are mainly because  A, multiplayer B, the drawn artstyle is amazing C, the gameplay itself is fun and challenging at the same time. struggling to stay alive and then surviving against all odds is just too fun. D, preparing and getting ready for certain things (winter, summer, giants, etc.) while annoying and time-consuming can be very rewarding. preparing for winter and just powering through instead of struggling throughout winter is so much fun. E. the mods, THE MODS. while some mods are simply furries having fun (which i'm neutral towards) there are some seriously good mods that either take away or add some challenge to the game.  if you have critisism or points that i've missed, tell me what i did wrong. just don't say stupid things.

Pros-  -Lots of new content, new dynamics, etc. since the original Don't Starve game. -Many different characters, all with their unique abilities, to choose from to play. -Survival game at its best: challenge, lots of things that can kill you, and just enough resources to help you survive. -You can haunt things when you're a ghost!   -Ability to make custom worlds allows you to tailor it to the survival skill level of you and your friends to make the game enjoyable without being overly frustrating.  Cons-  -The default world is very difficult, especially for beginners. Turn off Reign of Giants, make the days long, make winter short, and switch it from Survival to Endless. -Only 6 players can play in your world at a time. -No dedicated servers. If you're not online and hosting the world, your friends can't play.  Conclusion- If you like survival games & playing with your friends, you'll really enjoy Don't Starve Together.

This is a tough call as you'll definitely get your money worth in hours of gameplay and the game is fun until you realize that it's just a game of spinning plates.  As much as you want to be able to explore and do your own thing each day in game you find that you are in essense just ruled by the clock. There is always stuff that has to be done each day and there simply isn't enough time to get it all done even with extra people helping. There is a constant pressure of everything being required to prevent death.  - Need wood constantly because if you are in darkness at night you die. But of course you can't just go out and chop wood all day cause it pisses off the tree guardian then you've gotta spend a bunch of time dealing with that guy. - Need to gather or work on growing/cooking food because without food you'll die and pretty fast. And you've got to cook the food or you get nearly nothing for sustanance from eating it. - Need to search for other resources constantly to build weapons and gear that help ease the burden of your daily tasks. And protect yourself from the elements. Also your tools break so fast that 30% of what you gather goes towards the cost of crafting the items you need for gathering. - Need a stock of weapons and armor (which wear out really fast) because every few days the hounds attack or some other monster. - Have to go out and keep the local spider nests oppressed regularly because if you don't a spider queen will spawn and basically just kill you with ease then next time you try to go get some webs. - Need to also gather matierals for warm clothes and a stock pile of food in time for winter because you can't venture out too far or you will freeze to death unless you have warm cloths or warm rocks (that need to be recharged and replaced regularly). - Need to constantly monitor your sanity. Can't explore too much or see too much action in a short time and you have to sleep enough each day because if you don't you go insane. The only cure is taking a bunch of time to pick flowers, find and eat mushrooms...etc essentially wasting a bunch of time that you don't have cause winter is coming FAST!  ...and the list goes on. You are constantly under the gun of having to get 24 hours of crap done in 12 and just when you think you're ahead the game throws you a curve ball that completely ruins ya. After a while it just started feeling like work to me and the game was stressing me out more than it was entertaining me.  Yes there are lots of mods that allow you to control these aspects but I find that you really need to spend some time finding a good balance because when you stop all the need for the plate spinning you realize how dull the game actually is. The constant plate spinning distracts you from realizing there really isn't anything all that engaging on fun going on in the game - there's no story line or end game and once you've gone through the whole cycle of a year and explored the varied biomes there really isn't anything new to see.

This is a Tim Burton style survival game. From starvation to frostbite, from tenctacles to bees, you will die. Everyone will die when they play this game, so do not give up! Look up some tutorials/gamplays of Don't starve together. You can also have friends help you out and join your game. That way, you will not die (as quickly).   Overall: Overall, DST (Don't Starve together) is a wonderful game with quite a challenge. You will cry inside when you die, and dance when you make your first permanent base. Luckily for when you die, you can be resurrected by a friend,  touch stone, or the portal. Even though you can come back to life in DST, this game is unforgiving. Don't Starve was even more brutal (with permanant death) but still fun. DST has a lot of content and I recommend this for you. Good luck, don't give up, and, most importantly, DON'T STARVE (Together)!!

A classic game made into multiplayer. What's not to love? The excitement, the memories and more can now be shared with your friends, enemies or strangers.  To anyone thinking on getting it and playing with a friend, here are some tips to help you out. -Birchnut trees are a quick and safe way of getting food. Make sure to cut the trees with two branches at the top. -Be careful on what character you choose as they all have flaws but the best to start with is Wilson. -Always have some extra food on you. You'll never know when someone desperatly needs food. -Green Mushrooms are very good if you are low on sanity. Make sure too cook them though! -The best area to put a base in is near Beefalo  and a road for quick travel. -You do not have to fight spiders to get their silk/glands. Simply lure them into a trap and you get the resources trouble free! -Another say way of getting meat is by going near Moles, putting rocks/flint on the floor and waiting til they go out. Then attack them and you get a morsel without risk! -Treeguards can be be calmed by planting saplings of their trees near them. -Be careful when choosing Webber, as pigs will attack you on sight and you have lower sanity.  That's all i can think off the top of my head. Happy hunting and as always; Don't Starve (Together)

Love this game!!   I would probably rate this as one of my favorite survival games I've ever played. It's whimsical, cute, fun and immersive. The story behind the Don't Starve series is very well done and thought out. I'd suggest jumping down that rabbit hole if you have an hour or two to waste.  At first, it does feel slow and repetitive, but if you play through a little and start to understand the guts of the game, it'll become very addicting. I'm so in love with this game, I can play it for 6-10 hours straight if time permits.  I would definitely deem this game as hard, seeing as everything's purpose in the world is to kill you. However, once you survive 5-10 days, and get the basics down, it sucks you in.

อย่าหิว... ด้วยกัน.... ตัวนี้เป็นรีวิวพิเศษที่จะไม่มี ส่วนของ Story ครับ เพราะเกมเน้น Multiplayer โดยจะไม่มีคะแนนของเนื้อเรื่องสรุปตอนท้าย.. -Gameplay--------------------------------------------------------------- ตัวเกมนั้นนับได้ว่าถูกพอร์ทมาจาก Don't Starve ตัวหลักเลยก็ว่าได้ โดยเกมจะไม่เพิ่มอะไรไปมาก และ ตัดบางสิ่งออกเพื่อให้ตัวเกมนั้น เหมาะกับการเล่นแบบผู้เล่นจำนวนมาก ซึ่งนี่ก็ได้กลายเป็นดาบสองคมของเกมนี้ไปเลย โดยที่เกมเพิ่มระบบผู้เล่นหลายคน ทำให้ผู้เล่นที่มีปัญหาทางอินเตอร์เน็ตต้องเจอปัญหาหลากหลายรูปแบบ ถึงเกมนี้จะมีระบบที่ให้ผู้เล่นสร้างห้องกันเองก็ตาม แต่เกมนั้นก็ยังต้องการ Host ที่มีอินเตอร์เน็ตเสถียรเช่นกัน ซึ่งจะก่อให้เกิดปัญหา "Bad Host" ซึ่งผู้เล่น ในห้องจะเกิดอาการดีเลย์ทั้งๆที่เน็ตตัวเองไม่ได้ปิงเยอะรึมีปัญหาอะไรเลย แต่ในเมือเกมเพิ่มระบบนี่มา มันก็ทำให้เกมดูมีสีสันโดยคุณกับเพื่อนจะช่วยกันหาของรึสู้กับมอนสเตอร์ได้ง่ายขึ้น แต่ในทางกลับกัน สิ่งของก็จะมีจำนวนที่ต้องจำกัด และ แบ่งผู้เล่นอื่นตามๆกัน นับว่าเพิ่มความยากของเกมมาได้หลายเท่าเลย ใน Don't Starve นั้นหากผู้เล่นตายก็จะเป็นอันสิ้นสุดแต่ใน DST เมื่อคุณตายของคุณจะร่วงและคุณจะกลายเป็นวิญญาณ ซึ่งจำเป็นต้องให้เพื่อนร่วมทีมของคุณชุบชีวิตขึ้นมา และถ้าหากปล่อยให้เป็นผีแบบนั้น เกมก็จะดำเนินยากขึ้นเพราะมันจะลดกำลังในทีมไปได้ส่วนหนีง นับว่าผู้พัฒนาเกมได้ทำให้เกมดูร่วมมือกันตามชื่อ Together จริงๆ -Graphic----------------------------------------------------------------- อย่างที่รู้ๆกันว่าเกมนี้มีภาพ 2D ที่เป็นภาพวาด ซึ่งไม่ว่าใครๆก็คงเล่นได้ และไม่มีปัญหา แต่ว่า เกมนั้นยังมีปัญหากราฟฟิคที่แย่อยู่ เวลาที่คุณต่อสู้กับมอนสเตอร์จำนวนมาก รึมีการทำแอ็คชั่นในแมพนั่นมาก เฟรมเรทจะตก ซึ่งเรื่องนี้มันก็ไม่แปลก แต่ว่าเมื่อเวลาผ่านไป ทั้งๆที่เกมไม่ได้มีแอ็คชั่นอะไรมากมาย แต่เฟรมเรทมันก็ยังตกอยู่อย่างนั้น ซึ่งปัญหานี้จะพบกับ Host ซะเป็นส่วนใหญ่  -Verdict------------------------------------------------------------------ โดยรวมแล้วเกมได้เปิดมิติเกม Survival ที่ไม่เหมือนใครอย่าง Don't Starve ให้มาช่วยกันหิวได้ และเกมยังมีระบบ mods ที่ให้ผู้เล่นโหลดมาใช้มากมาย ถ้าคุณชอบ Don't Starve อยู่แล้วก็อย่าลังเลเลยครับ ชวนเพื่อนมาหิวด้วยกันเลย ราคาเกมไม่แพงจนเกินไปและไม่กินสเปค แต่มีปัญหาทางด้านเชื่อมต่อ ก็ไม่เข้าใจเลยว่าเกมภาพ 2D นี่มันจะ Host ห้องมันต้องใช้เน็ตแรงๆ และ สเปคเครื่องถึงขนาดสูงเลยรึไง ! ! !

I described the original [i]Don't Starve[/i] as "[i]The Sims[/i] meets [i]Castaway[/i], in the most flattering way possible." I never would've imagined its [i]Minecraft[/i]-like survival mechanics could actually improve with friends and family. [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] proves it does.  My wife and I were both big [i]Don't Starve[/i] fans by ourselves and [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] gave us the chance to thrive or die as one couple against the world. Like a real marriage, but with lots of weird, moody pets and no life insurance. It was love at first sight and our favorite multiplayer experience so far.  It includes all of the original game's DLC (except [i]Shipwrecked[/i], but similar seafaring mechanics have been implemented recently). That means all the crafting, the fighting and the conflict is here, only now it's a shared experience. Play with friends in your local network or against Steam members from all over the world. If you want, you can still play alone as well, but why would you? Seasonal and special events like [i]The Forge[/i] and [i]The Gorge[/i] are better enjoyed with people you know. It's also great to see what combination of characters you and your friends will pick to play together. Who will go for the legacy group (Wilson, Willow, Maxwell...) and who will pick one of the newbies (Wortox, Wormwood, Wurt...)?  While Klei didn't get around to making achievements for it, which I would've liked, they've managed to get me addicted with the game's skin drops. Collecting clothes, trading them, weaving them from discarded items and personalizing my character suddenly became just as important as keeping it alive.  Need another reason to play [i]Don't Starve Together[/i]? When you buy one, you get a free copy for a friend! Even better, if you owned the original before [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] was released, like I did, you may already own it for free! Either way, it's a must-buy for casual and diehard gamers alike!

The hounds always screw me over. Yet, I still haven't found the worst possible encounter. And I never want to. The survival elements are really frustrating, but that's what makes the game worth playing. you fail once and try again, hoping to get past another obstacle. Of course, once again, another wall is blocking your way. Going into a survival game and not knowing what it has in store is pretty thrilling.I've had a lot of fun building my way to the top and surviving for as along as possible. Although I fail in the end, I kept trying to see if I could get any better. Needless to say, this game is too hard for me. I suck complete beefalo dick.  Another amazing thing is the exploration. Adventure! I love it. So much content, new places to explore, new enemies, new resources, and new stinking HOUNDS! I think I would survive a lot longer if it weren't for the Hounds.  With all the new content coming, there's so much more to do than just survive!

The following is just a quick overview of the game for a full review check out my website at http://ausiejamster.wix.com/ausiesgamingzone#!dont-starve-together/ccpz  Don't Starve Together is a Co-Op/PvP survival game with the ability to be online or off. It is a multi-player remake of the original 'Don't Starve' game. Featuring most of the original content and characters, yet it doesn't include caves as well as the Reign of Giants downloadable content that the original 'Don't Starve' offers. Don't Starve Together is exclusive available on PC and purchasable from the steam store. I think the game's graphics are very good, I love the art-style and the polished content. The audio soundtracks are pretty decent, but aren't really to my style, although, it does suit the art-style of the game. The SFX, however, are amazing for the art-style, showing game designers that reaching out of the main stream sounds can still set a pretty decent scene, while adding to the player experience. It doesn't really have a story, however, you can easily extend the story from the original 'Don't Starve' Game. The game's content however doesn't have a massive downfall because of the lack of story as Klei Entertainment continuously update the game showing they do really care about it. The controls are pretty straight forward and decent with enough buttons to do what you want to do without having to try too hard, making the game easy to pick up. The difficulty of the game, I think is very solid not to hard but also not to easy, giving the game a lot of play time. There is some strategy to the game allowing the player to select the way they would like to produce their living essentials and whether it is stable in all seasons. There is no competitive side on this game at the moment, although, this might change in the future as Klei Entertainment is playing around with the PvP content. Overall I would give the game a score of 8.5/10 I do really think this game can have a lot of success in the future (as it is still in early access).

The game is okay, but without a victory condition, or at least, achievements/rewards for surviving a specific number of nights, the game quickly becomes repetitive and leaves you with a sense of "what's the point?"  This is a basic stat management game: manage your hunger, mental state, and life-points. You can play with your friends. That's the entire game summary.   Again, there's lots to enjoy here - nothing that hasn't been done - but this game is unfortunately missing a reward worth continuing to play for.

It is overally too much time consuming for an adult... probbably mostly a game for the non working youth that could find time to start all over again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again, only to see the days progress in numbers towards the infinity...

Don't Starve Together is a wonderful game. Although I haven't actually played *with* anyone yet, It's quite enjoyable. Also, don't be upset when you die. It happens to everyone. You'll die and die again. Tbh there's a lot of dying. And a lot of learning. It's not *super* beginner friendly, but you'll figure out the basics and go from there. (Also you can look to the wiki and such for help.)  I have a strategy for bases, though-  Like, I recommend you find the following three things -Beefalo, for manure and fur. also horns and meat. -Spiders, for silk. Monster meat can also be useful -Gold rocks/boulders. What more can I say? You need gold for a LOT of things.  I say, you should get this game, at least if it's your type of thing. Try, die, and try again. And die again.

The single player Don't Starve became stale for me after about 50 hours, so I was very excited when DST was released.   It is an unforgiving survival game, with unique mechanics (such as weather and sanity levels) that keep me busy even at 150 hours of gameplay.  The developers keep updating the game and there is so much content now with the addition of the cave system and Reign of Giants.   It is very funny too at times, like when your friend dies in a silly way or when friends don't appreciate how dangerous a fire staff can be and wave it around camp almost burning the whole place down twice.  Really fun crafting system, creepy atmosphere, well-balanced, a large variety of imaginative mobs and bosses, regular updates...do yourself a favour and convince a friend or two to play this game with you.

It's still missing quite a lot, but this 'vanilla' experience is still what Don't Starve (except with friends!) is known to be.   I more than recommend playing with others you know, because if game-anonymity has taught me anything, it can be a mixed bag with regards to who you'll be playing with.  With this, now you can laugh, cry, and otherwise have a few buddies experience the same things you do.  That being said, I'm using my previous review:  ---  Don't Starve and Dwarf Fortress share one thing in common; losing is fun!  The game itself is a huge learning experience, and you'll always get further (usually) the last time than you did the first time.  Even if you manage to make a self-sustaining base that was indeed somewhat indestructable, the game would lose a lot of what made it fun to begin with.  Of course, getting to said point requires said experience; which depending on the person may or may not actually come.  It's brutal at first glance, but even after you get better; the game doesn't stop getting harder.  If anything, the longer you live, the more merciless nature itself gets.  If you're not prepared, then prepare to die!

A fantastic game !  It actually took me some time to give this game a shot until i saw it being for sale and so i took my chance. Seriously i dont even regret that decision at all , besides some "small" things more for that later.  The artstyle is fantastic and i like those creatures and giants or those characters you can play,each with their own pro and cons and different stats.  Your main goal is to survive as long as possible and trying to get rid of those constant threats ,which are seasons ,giants or invasions and trying to avoid starvation or becoming insane,which can be sometimes really challenging ,but to make it even more challenging there are also players ,that tends to griefing by lighting your base on fire ,destroying stuff in there or just stand at base (,which you build to have an easier time or you play nomad style )and keep eating off your supply and ressources off in no time and trust me a lot of people do that and if you dont have people, that do stuff to surive together you find yourself rather being frustrated and annoyed from the game.  Actually there are people ,that complains that the community is toxic and ,if someone get seens/called griefing/griefer.He gets kicked rather quick from the server ,which some trolls tends to abuse.The big problem in this game are those people you play on random servers,which can make all your effort useless ,but i also gotta say ,that you barely get any information about what to cook or not ? for example. You can make crockpots to cook food. Sounds simple right ? Yes it is , if you know the proper recipes.You can get with 4 ingredints quite a lot of different foods,if you missplaced them or took too many of another one.So if you dont spent time on wiki or finding people ,that help you through the game.You might find yourself frustrated and hating on this game and may gonna say it's the worst game you ever bought for that price.  Still for that you can play with friends together and try to learn the game together ,which is a lot of fun and in general i recommend doing so to avoid randoms people,since 80% of them are trolls/griefer/eater aka just staying at base and eating everything ,thats in the fridge just like in real life :^)   However i still gonna recommend this game.Just because it's an amazing survival game with interesting ideas for characters and mechanics and lots of hidden secrets and quite a lot of stuff to discover or to learn,but there is one more thing ,that i might want to add.  This game has mod support ,which adds new characters into the game with their own functionality and QoL changes or more content in general.

Oh boy, another survival game for me to boot.  This game won't hold your hand for every little things that you do. You're basically free to do whatever you want! That doesn't mean you're up for a good time, though.  Being free to do everything doesn't mean you're allowed to do everything. Especially those who don't wanna learn how to stay alive in the game.  Unless you poured some hours onto the game, expect a non-forgiving survival, an uncompromising adventure of being stranded somewhere and forced to survive, gather resources, stave off hunger, and last but not least, hug the comforting fire pit that soothe your dreary night ahead while slowly losing your sanity.  IF, and IF, you're a survivalist type, this game is not too different from your usual cup of joe. I've played some harder survival game than this, but this game is definitely a start for newcomers, if they wanna learn the hardship of survival game while playing with different characters of one and another.  Main Wickerbottom? Immediate crafting for your former days and books usage for the latter. Main Wendy? Weak in term of hand-to-hand fighting, but a go-to if you want a friendly ghost that do stuff for you. Main Wigfrid? Those mobs won't stand a chance against your valkyrie might... but you despise veggies on your diet.  There are couple of ways to survive, and that is if you're playing alone.  It's called "Don't Starve TOGETHER", by the way. You're not alone, if multiplayer session is your choice. People across the world, or across your sofa, will be pitted in the same land to survive. Will you cooperate together and face the darkness, or, instead of trusting them of your well-being, you annihilate them, crush them like a bug, and force them outta the server because you're too good at fighting? There are times when you just wanna login and hangout, chat a bit, play it smooth and not to worry with dying, and luckily the game provides you with that as well, phew. What was that? I hear you just wanna watch the world burn thanks to your torch? Suit yourself in 'Madness' section and wreck havoc for your silly little enjoyment. Let your inner pyromaniac go do their thing, will ya?  You main Wes? Get ready to get hanged. NO. WES = BAD. NO WES, PLEASE. FILTHY WES MAIN, STAY AWAY FROM ME, YOU DISGUSTING CREATURE. AAAAAAA-

A fun but hard survival game that will kick your ass if you don't prepare for the winter and summer seasons.  As Wilson, grow a boring beard and watch everyone else do cool things with their abilities while shaving your beard.  As Willow, burn Wilson's base after stealing all of his food, then cook the food with your lighter and when you eventually go insane because the Wilson is haunting you drop your teddy bear Bernie Sander and watch it grow into a enormous size and slaughtering your living nightmares with universal healthcare.  As Wolfgang steal all of Willow's food and eat it all in one go to become mighty then go insane because of Willow's ghost but kill your living nightmares by yourself and go to youtube and make videos on why it's good to always be insane until you get killed by your living nightmares while fighting a boss and go complain on youtube and quit the game.  As Wendy use the power of your stand 「A B I G A I L」to farm spiders and hounds until Abigail decides to run off and attack a group of Mermmen but get's gang raped by them and dies again.  As WX steal and eat your friends gears that they were planning to make fridges out of and beg the Wickerbottom to electrocute you so you become even more OP, but then die when she uses the tentacle book on you because you stole gears.  As Woodie chop wood and make chests out of that wood, chop more wood and put that wood into the chest and make more chest once its full then become the werebeaver and run into the dragonfly and become beaver meat.  As Waxwell summon more stands to chop trees and fight for you but die once they die because you forgot how little HP you have.  As Wigfrid sell battle spears and helmets for meat but then die of starvation because everyone got football helmets and tentacle spikes instead.  As Webber set up your spider base in the middle of nowhere and cause a civil war but then accidentally set the nest on fire and die because there was a forest around it.  As Winona build spotlights as they are the best technology in the world and dodge a hit from Charlie while in the darkness because you craft slower than everyone else when you have less than 50 hunger and then die from starvation because it costs 5 hunger to craft above 50 hunger for a mere 0.5 second faster crafting speed.  As Wortox kill everything and eat their souls and heal with the souls and commit you are already dead by teleporting behind bosses.  As Wormwood plant a million seeds and have Wickerbottom make them all grow instantly for infinite food then die because you can't heal from food.  Oh and I forgot about Wes.  Wes is bes when hes ded.

I loved Don't Starve, and once I learned they were coming out with a game that let you play that same experience but with your friends; I was already sold. There's nothing more fun than spending a summer season clowning around with your friends to being murdered by a giant deerclops while freezing to death in the winter. Workshop support allows for a bit of extra tuning, and you're also allowed to adjust the world however you please on top of that through in game settings.   Bored friends and need something to kill time? This games it.

Originally I chose to ignore this game, thinking that it was something that I wouldn't like.  However, my daughter found it interesting and pointed out that there was a two for one offer, so I bought the two pack.  We've played the game together and I find it rather entertaining.  The music is quite good, hauntingly so, and adds to the ambiance of the game.  The atmosphere that the game presents appears to be something akin to Victorian Gothic, and the cartoony display of the characters lends to the overall playability of the game.  Overall, I'm glad that my original impression of the game has been proven wrong.  I would recommend it for anyone that likes survival-type games.

Don't Starve Together (along with its counterpart Don't Starve) have become by far one of my favorite games ever. The value is there in every capacity. Gameplay, story, characters, graphics/visuals, replayability, DLC/mods, sounds/music, and everything else is genuinely top notch. The game is challenging but not insurmountable, an amazing co-op (many say its co-op is better than single player), endearing but also thrilling and I could go on forever about all it's qualities. If you like survival or crafting games, you will love this game. I'd be shocked if you didn't, no matter what kind of games you like.

Don't Starve Together is an incredibly hard but fun rogue-like multiplayer game where teamwork means everything to one's survival. Taken straight from Edgar Allen Poe's fever dreams, a scientist named Wilson follows instructions given by a mysterious voice out of his radio. After having built a mysterious machine, he powers it on and it warps him to a world unknown to him. Wilson and his friends encounters many dangers in the wild as they try to find their way back home. And this time you get to enjoy the adventures online.  One thing you should know about this game is you're going to die. A LOT. Every time you die however, you'll have learned something new and you're going to come up with a new strategy to beat the game. But every time you think you've got it this time, you'll encounter new dangers and it's back to the drawing board. Don't Starve will not sit you down to read the instructions and expects you to find out what to do on your own. This steep learning curve provided me with many trips to the Don't Starve wiki. From playing with friends however, I also found value in the Steam Workshop, which comes with many fun custom characters to play, useful tools and game hacks to make the game a little less perilous. It should be said that I have never beaten the game before and it's so hard I've not even bothered with the DLC yet but it's still one of my favorite games on Steam. Definitely give it a try!

One of games that lets player craft his own story in a procedurally generated world.   My game play experiences are based on dying over and over again, thus finding more and more patterns and strategies relevant to survival. However essential parts of game are also hidden away from plain sight, thus I had to study resources outside of game.  Downside is that this game is a time sink - you can't pause without exiting game and quitting game midway breaks game play flow. Thereby DST encourages long game play sessions without any breaks, lasting for many hours.
good game

This is a very difficult game to review.  On one hand, this game is extremely difficult and will probably destroy any new player that approaches it, as the game offers next to no help to newcomers.  On the other hand, the game becomes extremely fun once you start to learn its mechanics, and probably one of the realest [b]survival[/b] there is. This game WILL try to kill you, regardless of the situation.   In the end I recommend the game to anyone that has the will to go and learn what it has to offer without backing down instantly in the face of its challenges.

A great way to spend an evening with your friends, trying to survive the world in DST when (no spoilers lol) the weather itself is probably your most dangerous enemy. By that I mean, compared to other enemies that you can kite, run away from, aggro to others, gang up on, you can't really run away from the cold or heat unless you've been diligently stocking up on seemingly useless things from previous seasons.   Also (my friends disagree but) getting insane is probably not the best idea, in this game or otherwise.   It's really addictive gameplay that easily brings back your adventurous spirit as you navigate and explore the world around you - a world all to yourself, free for you to do whatever you want with it, provided that you stay alive. Best to go blind into this game, and the slow but enjoyable learning process comes naturally as you spend hours into the game without realizing.   P.S: May have over-embellished my own experience but it's a game worth the price and the time. Played with friends or otherwise.

The original Don't Starve game was a quirky and charming little game, that while a bit rough (hard and unforgiving to a point), I grew to love as I played. I'm happy to say that Don't Starve Together is more of the same exciting fun, but with friends. The game contains some new content only found in it, such as new boss creatures, and provides a different kind of fun with friends in tow. I highly recommend this game, even if you have no one to play with, but is a sure fire buy if you know someone on your list who already has it.

A new world, a new adventure.  I love the dark aesthetic and the creativity that's put in each character. Each character has a different play-style, and it feels like playing a whole different game whenever you pick a different character: it makes it refreshing and very replayable. There's also quite a number of synergies between characters, and different strategies can be employed depending on which characters are available. Due to the nature of some harder creatures in the game, it is highly recommended to play with more players. Solo-playing can be fun and challenging, but it gets stale over time.  The most fun I have playing this game is with friends. Each new world feels like a rush, and each player has a significant role in the very critical stages of the early game. Teamwork is the key to survival. It's definitely a game made to be played with friends.

Really fun game, if you enjoy minecraft you are likely to enjoy this. However, less repetitive than minecraft, overall more challenging, each season brings a new challenge to overcome. One problem though is once you are fully loaded, the survival portion is pretty much taken out of the game, you no longer worry about dying. Still very fun to play with friends, and playing with strangers can add a lot of competition.

[h1]Positives[/h1] [list] [*] Sandbox playstyle [*] Unique characters [*] Great art style [*] Never a dull moment [*] Free content and updates [/list]  [h1]Negative[/h1] [list] [*] Steep learning curve [/list]  TLDR; [strike]Don't Starve Together (DST) is a great game to feel like you are in control of your own life.[/strike] (I'm joking!) DST is great for people who wants to co-operate with others to learn how to overcome an environment that is out to get you. It is both a co-operative game and a man vs system game.  [h1]Positives[/h1] [u]Sandbox playstyle[/u] DST is like minecraft, where there are many things to do. Harvesting, fighting, exploring, maintaining a base, etc etc. It is a game that allows the player to form their own goals/tasks. It is easy to get immersed in the world and lose many hours in one session of playing.   Despite playing 40+ hours, I still feel as if that I have not seen half of what the game has to offer!  [u]Unique characters[/u] It is rare these days, to have characters that are uniquely different from each other. (That being said, the game isn't very good at explaining the difference. It might be better to read up on what each character have to offer via the wiki.) The starting characters aren't just visual but each of them bring something different to the game and subsequently the server. Some characters excel in certain areas of the game and finding which one fits an individual playstyle is certainly a game all on its own.   Each character is also defined by an instrument and it is fun to not only see but also hear the difference!  [u]Great art style[/u] I mean, have you seen the screenshots? The characters, monsters and world is styled so differently from other games that it is easy to recognise the game through screenshots. Furthermore, the game love its puns in the name. (My personal favourite is [spoiler] Deerclops[/spoiler])   [u]Never a dull moment[/u] The game world is constantly changing. There are many things to learn and the moment you think you got the hang of it, the seasons changes, and each season brings their own troubles and benefits and everything in between.   [u]Free content and updates[/u] When I first picked up the game, I wasn't expecting that there were still future content to come. Especially when it is rare these days to not just ship them as a separate DLC. A big thank you, for the huge amount of content that we currently have and new stuff to come!  [h1]Negative[/h1] [u]Steep learning curve[/u] I only really have one, and that is the fact that it is not an easy game to introduce to new players. It is hard to balance the line between handholding and wanting to pass down important tips to a friend. I love the fact there are several ways to go about acquiring knowledge.   There is the wiki route, where even the wiki itself is massive and it is very easy to get lost in there. And that with the crafting system, there are layers to many knowledge that is offered.   There is the trial and error route, which takes more time but is very addicting. The feeling of knowing or learning something without any help is a huge morale and fun boost.   Otherwise, it is a great game to play with other clueless friends and be proud as both you and them learn the ways to navigate this world!

Day 1 - Collect some supplies and run across the island, I burn down trees and get charcoal. Yum Yum! Day 2 - I get this strange science machine and instantly, I get the better version because yay. Day 3 - I find chess robots who wanna kill me so I kill them in their sleep. Day 4 - I find a sack. I run and supply some more. Day 5 - I jump in a butthole to a different space. Day 6 - Set up camp. Firepit, Really good machine, Fridge, tent. Day 7 - I go hunt for the fancy pancy hat machine. Day 8 - Build it. Day 9 - I make me an effigy with my bear hair.  Skip to day 21 since all I do is harvest and get ready. Day 21 - Cold Winter comes and I am ready. I hunt some food with pigs and find a sheep. Nice. Day 22 - My two iceboxes and 6 crockpots aren't enough for me and 6 pigs. I make a pigwar and collect the droppings.  Day 25 - I shave and kill some cows for a lovely hat.  Day 26 - Hounds come and screw me up. Day 27 - I am weak, no fuel and all I got is twigs. Day 28 - I am freezing to death  Day 29 - I die but I be back.  Day 30 - I pick up my stuff and hunt for fuel. Day 31 - Deerclops comes, and fricks up my base. Day 32 - I die and cry.  overall i think this is a nice game when it comes to survivng.

I really like this game! I especially love the base building aspect combined with the survival aspect. By the way, if you're someone who wants to buy this game reading this right now, the game will probably seem very hard at first, but you can make it easier for yourself by changing the world settings before generating the world. Things like longer day, more recources and of course endless mode will make it way easier for you to learn to survive in the hostile don't starve worlds. Also looking for tips on youtube and the don't starve wiki can also do you wonders. Just watch out on youtube, there's some good youtubers, but there's a few toxic ones you should avoid like Edgy Rick. Overall I recommend this game.

Don't let the charming hand drawn, Tim Burton/Roman Dirge inspired graphics lead you into believing this game is in any way casual or easy, because it's not.   It's tedious, frustrating and impossible for many to even survive their 1st winter.  I think that's part of what makes this game interesting. Unlike most survival games, this one is actually challenging for you to survive. In fact, it's so challenging that it can drive players to the point of delusional paranoia and boot you from servers if they convey you as trying to sabotage their current game.  Because of this, I suggest only playing with friends, or single player mode.  The developers are great, and work to release a steady stream of updates and new content as needed.

If you are looking for a great open world, sandbox, survival and multiplayer game, then Don't Starve Together is the game you should buy. This game not only has unique artwork that makes every character and object look outstanding and unique, it also has very thoughtful ideas that make this game better than any other survival, open world, sandbox, and multiplayer game. This game is exciting, challenging, and fun to play for many hours, this game also provides countless opportunities and very many ideas for you and your friends to have lots of excitement. Don't Starve Together has one of the most unique and special artwork for the game, the art really fits the style of the game and it really makes the design and idea for the game stand out above any other survival or open world multiplayer game. You should get Don't Starve Together not only because it has very many exciting and fun things to do with your friends it also has a cool and unique design and feel to the game. I totally recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a game to play with their friends and to have lots of fun in a unique and amazing game.

I first bought this game in the mega pack for PS4. I had been looking forward to the local co-op since none of my friends had the game and I would be the first of them to try it. I loved it as I had hoped, but ended up playing the single player version more on PS4. My friends could not always play and I really have no desire to pay for Playstation Plus. I got the mega pack around when Wortox was released and not being able to purchase and play him really killed playing Together alone for me on PS4. It took chasing the Hamlet DLC for me to purchase a bundle on Steam and I don't regret it. All the features denied to me on PS4 I finally have access to and I am loving it. Too bad none of my friends can really play with me on this version like PS4. I suppose if there is some grand conclusion from my experience, it is that it is a great game; it is just that different platforms have pros and cons for this game and if you are interested in DLC it is for the single player version. That last part is a pro or a con depending on your preference, but I tend to be a fan of DLC for games I like. I would pay for it if I can access it, which I suppose is what the closet and special characters are for Together.

A fairly challenging survival game with a retro look.  Definitely worth a look if you like oddball survival games. Each world is randomly generated, so you run into different challenges each game. Each character has their own unique abilities and perks which adds to the randomness. Multiple layers of the game add to the fun. Explore caves and deal with different seasons. Watch out for winter as the bitter cold slowly kills you. The brutal summers melt you and burn everything around you. No single dimensional difficulty here folks.  Pick this game up period.

Review:  Pros: + Beautiful graphic + Not so easy survival with a lot of elements (weather, beasts, biotops...) + Lot of content and events  Cons: - In some cases very frustrating (for exam. You are boulding your base and suddenly there is huge monster with obssesion to destroy only your base) - Slow movement  Summary: This game is absolutely neccesary for every group of friends. Yeah you will cry, if your base get destroyed, but this is survival game. And ways of destiny are unpredictible. From me thumb up.

I've easily become obsessed with this game!   It's definitely always a struggle playing games with friends, and this one is no exception. Deciding who will get to eat next if there isn't an abundance of food is never a simple task, especially when you will all nearly end up suffering as a result. I've always wanted to play Don't Starve, and I feel that playing Together will give me the overall knowledge and skills that I will need to be successful playing on my own in the future.   This game is definitely based upon trial and error for those who don't look at online guides to be successful in games, and my only wish was there to be some sort of opening tutorial, to get first time users acquainted to the style and overall functions of the game easier.  Overall, I highly recommend this game to all.

This game is a great one emphasising both on teamwork and survival. I f you like survival games I would recommend this for you as you have to manage hunger, health and sanity. I love the fact that this game is filled with lore behind each and every character (more for some than others), as well as the fact that each and every character feels completely unique with Willow (The Firestarter) who takes longer to overheat but is quicker to cool down and starts with a teddy and a lighter, as well as Webber (The Indigestible) who can befriend spiders and upgrade their dens. Even though this is game is called Don't Starve Together it can be played alone (as I often do so) or with friends meaning you can share this experience with your friends. If you really want to play by yourself I would recommend Don't Starve as you can get extra content and new characters from DLCs (2-6 pounds I think) such as Shipwrecked which involves your characters being shipwrecked at the start and allows from the creation of boats and new characters and bosses along with new creatures.

This one is a sticky wicket. I love the games because they are super fun, but the together version keeps having its ups and downs. My personal experience with it isn't that good partially because everyone I've ever played with aren't cooperative, and when I try playing with my friends the connection goes awful. I also have had problems with the events and cosmetics system. While I like it and all, I don't like the idea of paying for things other than the base game. Events with the Forge got me upset because they were only limited time things and unfortunately they had some really cool cosmetics that were only available during the time. Other than that, it is a good entertaining game, and if you can run it, its good. Is it worth 15 dollars? If you can run a stable server and your friends have the game too, then it is worth every penny. Thanks for reading, educated buyer.

Absolutely love this game. It is a favorite of mine and I always enjoy coming back to it and starting a fresh playthrough. It's a fun and entertaining survival game filled with challenges that you can take on alone or with friends. The art style is unique and gives off Tim Burton vibes as many others have stated. At times, the game can either be relaxed, or outright crazy and challenging. All of the characters have their own unique strengths and weaknesses which create diverse and exciting challenges for the player. Each season in the game creates an even bigger challenge as you fight the weather and hope you don't die.  Overall, funfunfunfunfun. Love it.

(Disclaimer: I have never made it past 1 year in the game because I suck at it, so some of the more advanced information might be incorrect)  [h1]Design[/h1] The game has that nice old-school-silent-movie look to it with a good looking hand-drawn art style.  [h1]Gameplay[/h1] I find it best to go into the game blind and learning it all yourself [spoiler]The game is really hard by default, which is part of the fun, there is many things you need to keep track of and there is always something you need, be it something that will make surviving easier or something to fix something that has gone wrong like your food garden lighting on fire somehow. Often you need to make tough decisions like "should I eat this meat raw and risk future starvation or risk starving now so I can cook it so it fills me up for longer?" or "Should I eat this to keep myself from starving at the cost of taking damage?" or "Should I kill this taking damage or die in the process but possibly gain some good food to keep me fed for a while?" There are many fun and charming characters to pick from, none are better than each other but have their own advantages and disadvantages, they all have their own personality and play-styles. There are 4 seasons, each with their own challenges to overcome, freezing in the winter, insanity in the spring, overheating in the summer, and then there is autumn which is kind of your short break from the chaos to make sure you are prepared to do it all again. Your progression in the game does not come the game itself, but rather what you have learned, what to eat and what not to eat, how to make food into the best possible other food.[/spoiler]  [h1]Story[/h1] The game has a deep lore which comes after the story of "Don't Starve". I am not skilled enough at the game to reach the end of either and thus am not the right person to ask, play the game yourself or watch it on youtube if you want.

Don't Starve Together's visuals are STUNNING bringing Burtonesque elements into an explorable world! The controls are pretty tight and take little to no time getting used to. I would say that this game is a mix of survival/horror, strategy, and top-down combat. There are very few bugs that I have found within the 400 hours I have invested in this game so far. Playable characters have diverse mechanics that assist and support different playstyles. The humor in this game is subtle and hilarious. The game is fairly easy to mod for as well!  The music, world, and visuals tie together with a nice, neat, pretty bow. The mechanics are simple and there is no tutorial. The game itself if built to be explored and pokes and prodded at. I have logged hundreds of hours into this game and I am still learning new things!  Don't Starve Together is challenging without being awfully rage-inducing and allows the player to find multiple different ways to survive. It is a pleasant and enjoyable experience for anyone who loves the macabre!

Okay, so this game might not be for you if you're more into solid goals and objectives. Survival is a long-term objective and has way too many possibilities, you know? I tried playing this game with a bunch of first-timers and they were not having a good time. But as someone who has played the single-player mode quite a bit, HOOOO BOIII am I having a heck of a time.   You learn a lot from other players, you can fight together, and you gain a sense of companionship. What better way of feeling a sense of human connection than having someone feed you some nice warm food? I died earlier today because one of my fellow players was freezing and I tried to harvest some silk to make them a winter hat. No regrets :)  I would say the game has a bit of a learning curve since there are a lot of items that can be made. It definitely helps to have some recipes in your head especially because DST does not have a pause functionality. So this tip is for you, newbies: GO FIND SOME FLINT. - Flint + twigs = Axe -> Wood -> FIRE.  - Flint + twigs = Pickaxe -> Stone (and more flint!) -> FIRE PIT. See where I'm going with this?  Also some other principles I have in mind when I play: - If you find a road, try following it. It may not lead to anything fruitful but you gain extra movement speed on roads so might as well utilize it to explore more. - Poop is your friend. Bucket of poop is a better friend! - One of the first items you might want to try making is a garland. Watch your sanity! - Read the wiki in your free time and expand your knowledge. It will help.  Today I almost survived winter. Tomorrow I hope I can stay alive to tell the story. :P

Don't Starve is a great survival game with hidden story, and Don't Starve Together takes us further along in that story. I really enjoy playing DST, and have a fun time just logging on and playing on a random server. I often play on endless just to revive easily and not really have to worry about consequeces (except of course when your health is capped at 25% of your original health if you don't have Booster Shots). The workshop is very interesting too, seeing as you have client side and server side mods (I personally recommend the screaming rabbits mod, it's client side and makes all of the rabbits scream like grown men). The character customization is also the cherry on top for me, because I always like to give the characters my own personal touch. Long story short, Don't Starve Together is a great survival game, and I would recommend it.

I love this amazing game. The only change I would like to see is a Maxwell rework. I have started playing as him more recently, but his shadow fighters are useless later on. I would love to see if you could upgrade them to make them more useful, or specify them for certain bosses.

The art style is very charming, and so is the game play and characters. Though not everything is perfectly balanced, with some things needing serious nerfs and others needing buffs, it's still a nice experience which is even better with friends. (though lets be honest, how many of us have those? ha.   ha.         yeah...)  I will be honest, the multiplayer in most steam games I've played (excluding dedicated servers) is outright @$&*. Many of the other games I play suffer unbearable lag in multiplayer. This game is not one of those. The multiplayer runs very smoothly, regardless of who you may be playing with, and regardless of if it's hosted or if it's a dedicated server. (I have a friend who lives on the other side of the world and this is the only game we can play together without lagging to death) For those of you without friends, worry not! The multiplayer is not limited to friends only. There are many public worlds that you can hop into and meet new friends in! I can't guarantee that the people you'll meet will be friendly, though. It is survival of the fittest, after all.  The world customization is one of the best I've ever seen. Slight warning though: some of the settings are touchy (setting some resources to appear more often makes them practically flood the world, and setting some to appear less might make them practically nonexistent.)  The game's server-by-server modding is a very nice feature. I don't have to enable or disable mods each time I load up a different world, and can have different configurations for each one. It doesn't have world seeds, though, so cherish any world you generate that has a great start location.  This game is by no means easy, of course. If you've played the original Don't Starve, lots of the things in the world have gotten massive health boosts, which spells out doom for people trying to play alone. If you're not too good with these levels of challenges (like me) or don't have many friends to play with (also like me until a few days ago), I'm sure the workshop has something for you.  I give it a thumbs up.
